results.title: The Immortal story
results.creator_credit: Albina Productions, Office de Radiodiffusion Television Francais, Micheline Rozan and Orson Welles
results.brief_description: Orson Welles stars and directs (as he so often does, and does well) in this adaptation of Isak Dinesen’s (Karen Blixen) story. The story is from a novella and concerns a wealthy Macao merchant, Mr Clay (Welles) who attempts to prove his power by making an old seaman’s legend into fact. Welles cleverly uses the original story as a basis of a philosophical inquisition. Cast includes Orson Welles, Jeanne Moreau, Roger Coggio and Norman Eshley. Music by Eric Satie.

results.title: The Immortal battalion = The Way ahead
results.creator_credit: G C F, Two Cities Films, Norman Walker, John Sutro and Carol Reed
results.brief_description: Beginning as a British Army training film called “The New lot”, this film was then expanded into a feature length film written by Eric Ambler and Peter Ustinov, entitled “The Way ahead” for its British audience and re-edited into a slightly shorter film entitled “The Immortal battalion” for an American audience. Its basic concept is as a recruiting and training film for the British Army mixing training and combat footage with filmed sequences. The storyline is about a bunch of raw recruits from a variety of backgrounds who are finally welded into a unified and disciplined regimental unit ready for battle. Stars David Niven, Stanley Holloway, Peter Ustinov, Trevor Howard.

results.title: The Immigrant experience: the long long journey
results.creator_credit: Omaha-Orange Films, Linda Gottlieb and Joan Micklin Silver
results.brief_description: Focuses on the problems and dreams of new immigrants in America by telling about an uprooted Polish family. Shows how they lived at the beginning of the 20th century and includes interviews with the grandfather today as he reveals his contentment with improved opportunities for his grandchildren.

results.title: The Immigrant
results.creator_credit: Van Beuren Corporation and Blackhawk Films
results.brief_description: On their way to America, Charlie befriends a girl and her mother after an incident aboard ship. Later ashore they become involved in one of the funniest restaurant sequences ever filmed. One of the top Chaplin comedies of the mutual period. Cast also includes Edna Purviance, Eric Campbell, Albert Austin, Henry Bergman.

results.title: The Image of the city
results.creator_credit: Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Smithsonian Institute, Charles Eames and Ray Eames
results.brief_description: Based on the Eames exhibition ‘Photography and the City’ designed for the Smithsonian Institute. This documentary looks at the changing representation of cities based on the available technologies of the time. In the late nineteenth century photography not only provided popular views of distant monuments and foreign cities, but by rendering things and events objectively, became a valuable tool in the examination of social systems. At the turn of the century, photographers experimented with kites to capture aerial images of cities. Today [1969], specialists working in environmental fields are using a wide variety of photographic techniques to study and clarify urban problems. Tools such as multiband cameras, radar images , computer-generated graphics, satellite observations and thermograms are making available new information about our cities, their environment, and the influences upon them. Alex Funke, Parke Meek and David Olney involved in production, music by Gerald Fried.

results.title: The Image of empire: the early Roman Empire and the rise of christianity
results.creator_credit: Open University, British Broadcasting Corporation and Mary Hoskins
results.brief_description: How, in the absence of modern means of communication can a Roman Emperor project an image of himself and his rule? J. Ferguson discusses the various forms of imperial propaganda which included patriotic writing, the use of inscriptions, coinage, sculpture and public works.

results.title: The Image makers
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Adam Symansky, Peter Katadotis and Albert Kish
results.brief_description: A documentary about the National Film Board of Canada made to commemorate the Board’s 40th anniversary in 1979. It is a montage representing the work of over 400 people whose dedicated efforts have garnered over 1800 international awards for the Board. Sometimes majestic, sometimes whimsical, the film is a revue of a nation’s sights and sounds.

results.title: The Idol = L'Idole
results.creator_credit: Fidelite Productions, Olivier Delbosc, Marc Missonnier and Samantha Lang
results.brief_description: Directed by Australian Samantha Lang (The Monkey’s mask), this is a tale of two different souls who find solace in each other - and a kind of obsession. Set in Paris, France in an apartment block with a winding staircase that binds the people who live there. In an empty apartment opposite the elderly resident of Chinese origin called Zao (James Hong) arrives the beautiful and melodramatic Sarah (Leelee Sobieski), a young theatre actress from Australia. Sarah wants to feign a suicide to scandalise her relationship with her married lover but until she does the deed Zao asks that he may cook for her. Together they face the prospect of the end of life, love and sexual yearning - and an enjoyment of good food. Based on the novel “A L’Heure Dite” by Michelle Tourneur.

results.title: The Idiots = Idioterne
results.creator_credit: Zentropa Entertainments2 ApS, Dr TV, La Sept Cinema, Vibeke Windelov and Lars Von Trier
results.brief_description: The second of three films (“Breaking the waves” and “Dancer in the dark”) directed by Von Trier, The Idiots too is created using a female protagonist put in a stressful situation and as a work, was created adhering to the rules of the Dogme 95 Manifesto. Karen (Bodil Jorgensen) is a lone diner in a restaurant when a mentally retarded man starts to disturb everyone and creates a scene. He, his female helper and other male simpleton coax the good-natured Karen to leave with them in a taxi. Once along for the ride Karen discovers that the men were simply pretending to avoid paying the bill. But being an “idiot” is not something the men do infrequently, in fact they are part of a small community living in a large house of men and women who all take part in the practice of ‘spazzing’ or role playing ‘idiots’ to lose inhibitions both social and sexual. The group leader Stoffer (Jens Albinus) pushes everyone to the limit to see just how far they are willing to take the practice into their personal lives beyond the select commune atmosphere of the house. Offensive or funny, dramatic or pathetic, this film about, by and for idiots will certainly challenge some viewers. Shown in competition at the 1998 Cannes Film Festival. WARNING: SEXUALLY EXPLICIT
